Description: Paddle possibly used as an embalmer's tool. It was also interpreted as a model steering-oar from sacred boat from a model funerary barge or, judging by its size, from the processional bark of a god; the well-carved jackal-head on the butt suggest either Anubis or Wepwawet. The blade is slightly flattened and widened continuation of the loom, without a shoulder, and the loom is stout. Most of the length has been covered with a black substence containing beeswax, oil or fat, and a small amount of bitumen, which has been spread patchily over a considerable part of the surface and the jackal-head.
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Thebes (historic - Upper Egypt) (said to be from)
Curator's comments: Pair with .5505. Published in: D. Antoine and M. Vandenbeusch, Egyptian mummies. Exploring ancient lives, Sydney 2016, p. 42.
Bibliographic references: Glanville 1972 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum II: Wooden Model Boats (30)
